abstracts.cdata!:
The Highways Management Project for
            Thailand had a moderately unsatisfactory outcome, with the
            performances of both the Bank and the borrower deemed
            moderately unsatisfactory as well. While most of the project
            development objective indicators and intermediate outcome
            indicators were achieved fully or at least partially, three
            were not achieved. The reasons for the moderately
            unsatisfactory outcome were primarily the fact that some
            targets were not achieved, and also because certain
            important social issues were not addressed specifically
            during project implementation. Significant lessons learned
            during the course of implementing the project were: 1) the
            Bank should assess the interest of the borrower for proposed
            activities carefully, and should not push its own agenda.
            The implementing agency also should assess its own interests
            and ownership of project activities seriously and convey
            them clearly; 2) usage of additional financing for
            "scale up" should be examined carefully; 3)
            performance indicators and targets should be clearly defined
            and the monitoring process should be agreed firmly at
            appraisal; 4) improving road safety needs continuous
            efforts; and 5) the fiduciary requirements for middle income
            clients need to be monitored carefully.
